title: Pilot Trial of Carvedilol in Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: This is a 6-month pilot randomized double-blind placebo-controlled trial of carvedilol, with the primary objective being to determine whether carvedilol treatment is associated with improvement in Alzheimer's Disease (AD) as compared to placebo treatment. Secondary objectives are to monitor changes in cerebrospinal fluid amyloid levels and whether this dose will be safe and well-tolerated in AD patients. Clinical assessments will be performed at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months, while cerebrospinal fluid and blood samples will be obtained at baseline and 6 months.
description_detailed:
The purpose of the study is to measure decline in episodic memory in participants with early AD taking carvedilol compared to placebo treatment as evidenced by the Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT). cerebrospinal fluid levels of Aβ oligomers in early AD, will be measured in participants receiving carvedilol treatment when compared to placebo treatment. Adverse effects will be monitored in participants receiving carvedilol when compared to placebo.

To assess adverse events, routine chemistry and hematology studies, vital signs, and electrocardiographic parameters before and after 6 months randomized placebo-controlled double-blind treatment with carvedilol at a target dose of 25 mg daily, comparing 25 early AD participants taking carvedilol vs. 25 early AD participants taking placebo.

groups.title: Carvedilol
groups.description:
Carvedilol is a is a beta-blocker. Beta-blockers are generally used to reduce the workload on the heart and help it to beat more regularly.

Carvedilol: target dose of 25 mg daily which is half the maximum dose used in clinical practice

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description:
Non active substance

Placebo: a pill that will look like the active drug but will not contain any carvedilol

outcomeMeasures.title: Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT) Scores at Baseline, 3, and 6 Months
outcomeMeasures.description: The investigators measured episodic memory (as evidence by the Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT)) before and after 6 months randomized placebo-controlled double-blind treatment with carvedilol at a target dose of 25 mg daily. Changes in HVLT Immediate and Delayed Recall score in 14 Alzheimer's Disease (AD) participants taking carvedilol vs. 15 AD participants taking placebo were compared. HVLT test score ranges are as follows: immediate recall (0-24) delayed recall (0-12). Higher scores indicate better episodic memory recall.

groups.title: HVLT Score in Placebo Group
groups.description: Descriptive statistics for immediate recall in the Hopkins Verbal Learning Test in the placebo group

groups.title: HVLT Score in Treatment Group
groups.description: Descriptive statistics for immediate recall in the Hopkins Verbal Learning Test in the treatment group

analyses.groupDescription: This analysis compares immediate recall before and after 6 months between the treatment and placebo group.

outcomeMeasures.title: Effect of Carvedilol Treatment in Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Levels of Amyloid-beta Oligomers
outcomeMeasures.description: The investigators will measure CSF Abeta oligomer levels before and after 6 months randomized placebo-controlled double-blind treatment with carvedilol at a target dose of 25 mg daily, comparing the change in levels in 6 AD participants taking carvedilol vs. 10 AD participants taking placebo. These 16 participants had both baseline and 6 month CSF collected (of the entire study population). CSF was collected at the baseline visit and 6 months later.

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is carvedilol, a small-molecule, nonselective beta-adrenergic blocker (with additional alpha-1 vasodilatory and other actions), not a biologic. citeturn0search6turn0search7

Act (extracted details): The trial is a 6-month randomized double-blind placebo-controlled pilot testing carvedilol vs placebo in early AD, with primary clinical cognitive endpoints (HVLT/episodic memory) and secondary measurement of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) Aβ oligomers/amyloid levels (NCT01354444). This shows the study is explicitly evaluating potential effects on AD pathology (amyloid) in addition to cognition. citeturn0search1turn0search2

Supporting evidence that carvedilol has been hypothesized to affect AD pathology: Preclinical work reported carvedilol reduced brain oligomeric Aβ and improved cognition in AD mouse models, providing a rationale for measuring CSF amyloid in the clinical trial. citeturn0search9turn0search0

Classification decision: Given carvedilol is a small-molecule drug and the trial specifically measures CSF amyloid/oligomers (i.e., testing a potential disease-modifying effect on AD pathology), the trial best fits the 'disease-targeted small molecule' category rather than 'cognitive enhancer' or 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement.'

Reflect: Although carvedilol is primarily an approved cardiovascular agent, the trial’s design and endpoints indicate a hypothesis that carvedilol may alter Alzheimer’s pathology (amyloid oligomers). If one emphasized only its usual clinical indication (beta-blocker), one might argue it is not an AD-targeted agent by original intent; however, the presence of pathology-focused secondary outcomes and supporting preclinical data justify classifying this specific AD trial as testing a disease-targeted small molecule. citeturn0search9turn0search1
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is carvedilol (a small‑molecule, nonselective β‑adrenergic blocker with α1 vasodilatory and other actions), but the trial was designed to test potential disease‑modifying effects on Alzheimer's pathology by measuring CSF Aβ (including oligomers) in addition to cognition. citeturn0search2turn3search0

Act: Extracted details — drug: carvedilol; trial design: 6‑month randomized double‑blind placebo‑controlled pilot in early AD with primary cognitive endpoints (HVLT) and a secondary outcome of CSF Aβ/oligomers (NCT01354444). Preclinical studies reported that carvedilol reduced brain oligomeric Aβ and improved cognition in AD mouse models, providing the mechanistic rationale for the amyloid outcome measurement. Based on the explicit amyloid/oligomer endpoints and supporting preclinical evidence, the most specific CADRO category is A) Amyloid beta. citeturn3search0turn1search1

Reflect: Although carvedilol’s canonical pharmacology is adrenergic blockade (and it has other actions), CADRO classification is guided by the biological target(s) evaluated in the AD trial. Because this trial explicitly tested effects on amyloid/oligomers (a primary disease pathology) and was framed as a disease‑targeted small‑molecule trial, classifying it under A) Amyloid beta is the best fit. If one focused only on the drug’s usual cardiovascular target (adrenergic receptors) and ignored the trial’s AD pathology endpoints, an alternative classification (e.g., Other) could be argued, but the trial’s design and preclinical rationale justify A). citeturn0search2turn1search1

Web sources (supporting evidence cited above): clinical trial record describing design and CSF Aβ/oligomer endpoints (NCT01354444). citeturn3search0; preclinical paper reporting carvedilol reduced brain oligomeric Aβ and improved cognition in AD mouse models. citeturn1search1; carvedilol pharmacology (nonselective β‑blocker with α1 activity and additional signaling properties). citeturn0search2
